Important Admissions Information for Fall 2026


ALL MAJORS ARE IMPACTED at California State University, Long Beach. As a result, incoming students must complete a series of major-specific preparation coursework and meet GPA requirements. Please visit our Major Specific Degree Requirements webpage for more information and to find the correct path and year for your major.


Review the following for information related to transfer admissions to CSULB:

  • Transfer Admission Eligibility Overview
  • Transfer Application Process
  • Lower Division Requirements Information for Major Agreements


Due to ASSIST text limitations, some information regarding upper-division course options and electives may not be clear below. It is strongly recommended that agreement information along with CSULB Catalog information be reviewed when assessing a degree's requirements. It is crucial to note that the lower-division course requirements may change from year to year. The specific course requirements (catalog rights) will be determined for the student based on the catalog in effect at the time of their first term at CSULB. While effort is expended to mitigate alterations, agreement language can change with little advanced notice.

All College of Business majors must maintain major GPAs of 2.0 or higher.


Critical Thinking: Students can take any critical thinking course (GE category 1B); I S 100 is recommended.


Computer Proficiency: Students can complete I S 233 (or its equivalent) or achieve a passing score of 70% on the Computer Proficiency Exam (CPE). Transfer equivalent course with a 'C' or better grade.


Consult the CSULB Catalog for additional details

The Bachelor of Arts in Comparative World Literature offers three (3) emphasis options:

 

  • Emphasis I: World Literature in Translation.
  • Emphasis II: Cultural Studies. Cultural Studies is the interdisciplinary study of literature and other forms of cultural expression within social and historical contexts. All courses are upper division.
  • Emphasis III: Language and Literature. A second foreign language study is encouraged but not required for this emphasis.


PLEASE REFER TO THE ENTRIES FOR THE INDIVIDUAL OPTIONS FOR SPECIFIC MAJOR PREPARATION

Cultural Studies is the interdisciplinary study of literature and other forms of cultural expression within social and historical contexts. This emphasis offers a core of literature classes and an interdisciplinary pattern of cultural studies courses from the Liberal Arts. All courses listed in the requirements are upper-division and do not appear in ASSIST agreements. 


Consult the CSULB Catalog for additional details.

Agreement Information


The information below represents a view of articulated lower-division courses between California State University, Long Beach (CSULB) and the sending institution, aligning with the CSULB academic catalog. On the left, the CSULB courses are listed, while any corresponding articulated courses are displayed on the right. It is essential to note that degree requirements may involve various combinations of courses or additional instructions; consequently, a careful review of all relevant information associated with the agreement is advised.


Important Admissions Information for Fall 2026


ALL MAJORS ARE IMPACTED at California State University, Long Beach. As a result, incoming students must complete a series of major-specific preparation coursework and meet GPA requirements. Please visit our Major Specific Degree Requirements webpage for more information and to find the correct path and year for your major.


Review the following for information related to transfer admissions to CSULB:

  • Transfer Admission Eligibility Overview
  • Transfer Application Process
  • Lower Division Requirements Information for Major Agreements


Due to ASSIST text limitations, some information regarding upper-division course options and electives may not be clear below. It is strongly recommended that agreement information along with CSULB Catalog information be reviewed when assessing a degree's requirements. It is crucial to note that the lower-division course requirements may change from year to year. The specific course requirements (catalog rights) will be determined for the student based on the catalog in effect at the time of their first term at CSULB. While effort is expended to mitigate alterations, agreement language can change with little advanced notice.

All students must achieve a 'C' or better grade in all courses in the major.


ENGR 101 & ENGR 102 are waived for all transfer Engineering students. 


Degree Progress: Transfer students must complete within one year after transfer to CSULB, both MATH 123 (Calculus II) and PHYS 151 (Mechanics and Heat), with a ‘C’ or better if the equivalent was not taken prior to transfer.


Contact the Engineering Student Success Center (ESSC) advising office at (562) 985-1800 or coe-advising@csulb.edu with any questions.


Consult the CSULB Catalog for additional details.

All students must achieve a 'C' or better grade in all courses in the major.


ENGR 101, ENGR 102, & CECS 105 are waived for all transfer Computer Science students

Approved Science Electives (minimum of 8 units)


Take a minimum of 8 units of approved science electives to include a two-semester science sequence chosen from the following groups of courses:

  • PHYS 151 - Mechanics and Heat (4 units)

or

  • CHEM 111A - General Chemistry (5 units)


Remaining units to be chosen from the following:

  • BIOL 200 - General Biology (4 units)
  • BIOL 205 - Human Biology (4 units)
  • BIOL 207 - Human Physiology (4 units)


Contact the Engineering Student Success Center (ESSC) advising office at (562) 985-1800 or coe-advising@csulb.edu with any questions.


Consult the CSULB Catalog for additional details.

While effort is expended to mitigate alterations, agreement language can change with little advanced notice.

Students intending to transfer from community colleges to this University for a bachelor of science degree in criminology and criminal justice are advised to complete general education requirements while attending the community college.


All students must achieve a 'C' or better grade in all courses in the major.


Each course on the student's program planner must be completed with a grade of 'C' or higher. In addition, a course in which a grade lower than 'C' is received must be retaken and successfully completed prior to enrolling in a course for which it is a prerequisite. A student receiving a grade lower than a 'C' may proceed with other courses with the approval of the Undergraduate Advisor. 


Courses equivalent to CRJU 101, The Criminal Justice in Society, and two lower-division cognate courses (SOC 100, PSY 100, and POSC 100) should be taken while attending community college. Other criminal justice courses taken at community colleges will be accepted as lower-division electives provided the college where they were taken designated them as transferable to CSU. These courses cannot be substituted for upper-division criminal justice courses.


Consult the CSULB Catalog for additional details.

Bachelor of Arts in Global Studies is an interdisciplinary degree program that marries a strong liberal arts education with a foundation in transecting international studies theories and a professionally oriented skillset necessary for success in internationally related careers.


The language requirement notes:


Students can complete the foreign language requirement as follows:

  • a) Complete 3 units of a second language taken at the 200-level at CSULB. -- or
  • b) Complete 3 units of a second language taken at the 200-level or equivalent at another institution. -- or
  • c) Demonstrate 2nd-year level proficiency in a second language, subject to approval by the Global Studies advisor.


It is recommended to reach out to a department advisor if a transfer applicant has any questions about the language requirement.


Consult the CSULB Catalog for additional details.

Three degree options compose the Bachelor of Science in Health Care Administration:


  • Bachelor of Science in Health Care Administration (general)
  • Bachelor of Science in Health Care Administration, Option in Healthcare Data Analytics
  • Bachelor of Science in Health Care Administration, Option in Risk Management and Safety


All three options require the same undergraduate coursework (below) for transfer applicants.


Additional Information


Computer proficiency in word processing, spreadsheet, database, and presentation software is expected.


  1. All students must achieve at least a 2.5 grade-point average for entrance into the program.
  2. All students must achieve a 'C' or better grade in all courses in the major.


Please contact academic advising or the department staff if you have any questions. 


Consult the CSULB Catalog for additional details.

History majors are strongly encouraged to include the study of a foreign language and literature in their programs.


Students are also required to take one history course that fulfills the gender, race, and ethnicity requirement (from a list of approved courses available from the Undergraduate Advisor).


Group 3: The History/Social Science teaching specialization is designed for prospective secondary History/Social Science teachers. Students receive a B.A. in History, but they complete a sequence of classes that satisfies the state-mandated requirement in subject matter competence for the Single Subject Teaching Credential. Complete Group 3 and all upper-division courses.


Group 4: Students should select US History as one of their fields of emphasis. Complete Group 4 and all upper-division courses.



Consult the CSULB Catalog and History department for additional details.

The text limitations of ASSIST make it difficult to share all information related to the lower-division requirements for the Liberal Studies, BA. It is strongly recommended to review these agreements below with the CSULB Catalog for the Liberal Studies, BA.

The Liberal Studies Core: A minimum of 102 units distributed in Areas I Language Arts, II Mathematics, III Natural Science, IV History-Social Science, V Arts and Humanities, VI Critical Issues in Teaching and Learning. No core classes may be taken for Credit/No Credit. All courses in the Liberal Studies Core must be completed with a grade of C or better. The Department of Liberal Studies is the only authorized department to provide further substitution for any of the unarticulated lower and/or upper-division courses below. Please contact the department for further evaluation or refer to the Liberal Studies website for a list of additional courses approved for this program that may not appear here. The list can be found in the Community College Transfer Credit Guide.

Language requirement: Students must complete a fourth-semester-level course or demonstrate equivalent proficiency in a language other than English. Alternatively, a student may complete two second-semester level courses in two different languages, including at least one language from outside the Indo-European family. A list of applicable courses may be obtained from the undergraduate advisor. This may require 0-16 units of coursework, depending on the language studied and the student's initial placement level. Students with prior language experience can pass all or part of the language requirement by examination or other evidence.


Consult the CSULB Catalog for additional details.

All students must achieve at least a 2.0 grade point average.


BIOL 111, BIOL 111L, BIOL 212, BIOL 212L, BIOL 23, and BIOL 213L are required if courses were taken prior to the catalog year 2010-11.


These courses do not meet any specific or elective requirements for this major:

·       BIOL 101 - Introduction to Human Disease (3 units)

·       BIOL 153 - Introduction to Marine Biology (3 units)

·       BIOL 153L - Introduction to Marine Biology Laboratory (1 unit)

·       BIOL 200 - General Biology (4 units)

·       BIOL 200L - General Biology Laboratory (1 Unit)

·       BIOL 205 - Human Biology (4 units)

·       BIOL 205L - Human Biology Laboratory (1 unit)

·       BIOL 207 - Human Physiology (4 units)

·       BIOL 208 - Human Anatomy (4 units)


Few, if any, health-related professional schools (e.g., veterinary medicine) will accept CHEM 227. Some graduate programs with masters or doctorates in biology and/or marine biology may also not accept CHEM 227. Students interested in these programs might consider taking PHYS 100B or PHYS 152; MATH 119B or MATH 122; CHEM 220A, CHEM 220B and CHEM 223A, CHEM 223B. CHEM 227 is not acceptable as a prerequisite for CHEM 441A. CHEM 227 is acceptable toward the Minor in Chemistry.


Chemistry Department Note: Because the course topics at different institutions may not be parallel, the CSULB Chemistry department strongly recommends that students complete multi-semester or multi-quarter sequence chemistry courses at a single institution.


Consult the CSULB Catalog for additional details.

All entering Music students are required to take a theory placement test and performance audition prior to admission to assess performance standards. Each entering student should inquire at the Conservatory Office for dates and details. The office can be reached at (562) 985-4781.


All applicants to the program must meet with the B.A. advisor prior to, or at the beginning of, the first semester of residence to review the statement of purpose and to draw up an individualized study plan.


Major Performance Organization - please note the following text from the Catalog:


  • All Music Majors must audition for an MPO in their area each semester and must participate in the MPO as determined by audition. Participation in additional ensembles may be used as electives.
  • MUS 100 MPO, minimum of 4 units with concurrent enrollment in MUS 129
  • Piano: Take MUS 100 A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, or J.
  • Strings: Take MUS 100 H, I or J.
  • Woodwinds, Brass, and Percussion: Take MUS 100 A, B, or C.
  • Vocal: Take MUS 100 D, E, F, or G.
  • Guitar: Take MUS 100 A – P or MUS 200 B, J, or W. 


Performance Ensembles must meet Conservatory approval.


Applied Music must also complete the Upper-Division Screening Exam (UPSE).


Piano Proficiency must be demonstrated by successful completion of the piano proficiency exam (equivalent to MUS 220B).


Consult the CSULB Catalog for additional details.

Note: All entering Music students are required to take a theory placement test and performance audition prior to admission to assess performance standards. Each entering student should inquire at the Conservatory Office for dates and details. The office can be reached at (562) 985-4781.


All applicants to the program must meet with the B.A. adviser prior to, or at the beginning of, the first semester of residence to review the statement of purpose and to draw up an individualized study plan.


Performance Ensembles or Major Performance Organization (MPO) must meet Conservatory approval with audition.


Major Performance Organization Catalog Text:


  • All Music Majors must audition for an MPO in their area each semester and must participate in the MPO as determined by audition. Participation in additional ensembles may be used as electives.
  • MUS 100/MUS 300 MPO, one topic each semester in residence.


  • Piano: Upon passing the Upper Division Screening Exam (UDSE) piano students may take MUS 400 (topic U) for MPO.
  • Strings: Take MUS 100/MUS 300 (topics H, I or J) or MUS 200/400C.
  • Woodwinds, Brass, and Percussion: Take MUS 100/MUS 300 (topics A, B, or C).
  • Vocal: Take MUS 100/MUS 300 (topics D, E, F, or G).
  • Opera: Take at least 6 semesters of MUS 100/MUS 300 (topics D, E, F, or G) and at least 2 semesters of MUS 330.
  • Jazz Studies: Take at least 4 semesters of MUS 100 (topics A, B, C, E, F, G, I, or J). Upon passing the Upper Division Screening Exam (UDSE) take MUS 300 (topics K, L, M, N, O, or P) for a minimum of 4 semesters. 


Keyboard Proficiency must be demonstrated by successful completion of the Conservatory’s piano proficiency exam (equivalent to MUS 220B) (piano majors excepted).


Brass:

  • Take two units from MUS 200/MUS 400
  • If taking MUS 224, take MUS 224A
  • If taking MUS 424, take MUS 424A
  • Take MUS 100J


Woodwind:

  • Take two units from MUS 200/MUS 400
  • If taking MUS 224, take MUS 224B
  • If taking MUS 424, take MUS 424B
  • Take MUS 100J


Percussion:

  • Take two units from MUS 200/MUS 400
  • If taking MUS 224, take MUS 224C
  • If taking MUS 424, take MUS 424C
  • Take MUS 100J
  • Take MUS 200M


Strings:

  • Take six units from MUS 200 (Topics B, D, H, P, or S) or MUS 400 (Topics B, D, H, P, or S)
  • Take two units from MUS 224D or MUS 242D


Voice:

  • Foreign Language Requirement: Completion of Language Examination in French, German, or Italian may be waived by completion of FREN 101B, GERM 101B, or ITAL 100B.


Pre-Professional Studies in Opera:

  • Foreign Language Requirement: Completion of Language Examination in French, German, or Italian may be waived by completion of FREN 101B, GERM 101B, or ITAL 100B.
  • Choose two courses from the following:
  • Theatre Elective (3 units)
  • Dance Elective (2 units)
  • DANC 113A


Jazz Studies must be demonstrated by successful completion of the Jazz Piano Proficiency Exam (or equivalent to MUS 221B.)

  • Take MUS 100 or MUS 100L or MUS 100M or MUS 100N or MUS 100O


Consult the CSULB Catalog for additional details.

The Department of Nursing offers two bachelor's degrees:


  • Bachelor of Science in Nursing - Basic
  • Bachelor of Science in Nursing - Registered Nurse

Nursing Basic: Criminal background checks, health insurance, immunizations, medical clearance, and malpractice insurance are required for clinical coursework.


Consult the CSULB Catalog and major-specific degree requirements for additional details on Nursing Basic.


RN students must:

  • 1) Hold a current license or be eligible for a license to practice in California
  • 2) Graduation from an Accredited Associate Degree program or evaluation of diploma program for equivalency by an Accredited Associate Degree program
  • 3) Have 56 to 70 transferable units including statistics and a 5-unit chemistry course (CHEM 140 preferred);
  • 4) A minimum GPA of 2.75 in all community college courses required for the Associate Degree in Nursing
  • 5) Maintain malpractice and health insurance throughout clinical coursework and submit to a criminal background check
  • 6) Attend a group counseling session for RN students and complete the RN application form;
  • 7) Submit official transcripts of any previous college work to the School of Nursing;
  • 8) Fulfill the Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement (GWAR) either prior to admission or within the first semester in the program.
  • Prerequisites: Satisfactory completion of an undergraduate statistics course suitable for general education math credit and an inorganic, organic, and/or biochemistry course.


Consult the CSULB Catalog and major-specific degree requirements for additional details on Nursing, RN.


Prerequisite lab courses taken with an online laboratory during the COVID-19 pandemic will be accepted.
